subject: tudu
title: #75 "CannotCreateTransactionException" on first view each day
description:
I installed version 2.3 of tudu lists on my own server (which is a continuosly running ubuntu server machine, I've installed tudu-lists to run on tomcat 6 and to use the latest mysql version that comes with ubuntu server), and it's working very nicely - apart from one little problem:
Every day when I first navigate to the tudu-lists application, the attached stack trace shows up instead of the todo list, along with the rather unhelpful error message "An error has occured.".
When I hit refresh 2 or 3 times, it starts working again as expected, the data is still here and everything's fine. So I don't need to do anything except refreshing a few times - but this strikes me as very odd behavior. Why does it fail the first few times, and why does it work again afterwards?

I guess it's probably a configuration issue on my side, but I have no idea where to start looking... Anyone got an idea what could be wrong here?
Stacktrace appearing the first few times each day when accessing tudu-lists

You probably have a problem with your connexion pool, this is quite common with MySQL. Can you post your configuration?
The solution would be to use c3p0 instead of commons-dbcp, anyway.
• assigned_to: nobody --> roullian

Thanks for your suggestion, sorry it took me so long to do anything about it.
With configuration, I guess you mean the applicationContext-jpa.xml?
actually I couldn't find any simple instructions on how I would replace commons-dbcp with c3p0; but I tried another thing instead, namely adding these two lines to my BasicDataSource tag:
<property name="testOnBorrow" value="true"/>
<property name="validationQuery" value="SELECT 1"/>
(as suggested at http://javathings.blogspot.com/2009/04/fix-for-timeout-on-dbcp-connections.html\).
Supposedly that makes commons-dbcp check a connection before it is handed out to an application, and it seems to have helped.

Yes, it works exactly has you describe, and it indeeds solves the problem. The only issue with this solution is that you double the number of SQL requests sent to the database. The "select 1" is of course of trivial request, but you still lose time waiting for the network.
Anyway, it solves the problem, so I'm closing the issue.
• status: open --> closed-fixed

subject: tudu
title: #55 web.xml not portable
description:
web.xml included in tudu lists is not a valid XML Document. This affects the portability of tutu lists as a J2EE application, when it is deployed on other servers.

Whats wrong ?
-------------
Each of the web.xml in tudu lists specifies the web-app schema location like this :

xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/web-app_2_4.xsd"

But according to XML Schema 1.0 spec at http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-0/#schemaLocation,

The schemaLocation attribute contains pairs of values: The first member of each pair is the namespace for which the second member is the hint describing where to find to an appropriate schema document.

Here's an excerpt from Sun's J2EE 1.4 RI samples:

<web-app version="2.4" xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee
http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/web-app_2_4.xsd">

Fix :
-----
Hence each occurrence of in each of the identified web.xml files
xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/web-app_2_4.xsd"

should be changed to

xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/web-app_2_4.xsd"

Also See : http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/tomcat-dev/200401.mbox/%3C20040115165839.11772.qmail@nagoya.betaversion.org%3E

Following are the affected files :
./sources/tudu-presentation/tudu-dwr/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-presentation/tudu-flex/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-presentation/tudu-gwt/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-presentation/tudu-portlet/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-presentation/tudu-springmvc/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-presentation/tudu-springwebflow/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-ws/tudu-axis/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-ws/tudu-xfire/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml
./sources/tudu-ws/tudu-xfire-jaxws2/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml

• priority: 5 --> 8
  • assigned_to: nobody --> roullian

That's not a bug that's a feature :-)
There is no such thing as a list owner, in fact. The idea is
that everybody has the same rights. If you share a list with
someone, you are supposed to trust him.
In a work environnement, the idea is that members of the
team are intelligent enough to track their todos themselves.
It's not a hierarchy-driven method of working. There should
still be a team leader, but he does not need to have a
special access to the system to have some authority on his team.

subject: tudu
title: #4 Problem with sharing
description:
I noticed that if someone shared a todo list with me I
could remove them as users of the list. I decided to
make this apparent by stealing all of the test to-do
lists in doing so I broke parts of my account.. the
ability to edit access to todo lists and add to do

test account.

scbysnx is my account and if you can't access my

xh6cx8n02@sneakemail.com

I used a sneak e-mail account because I didn't want my
e-mail address out in the open

Logged In: YES
user_id=79744

This, in fact, is normal behavior.

There is nothing as a "list owner". Tudu Lists is a
collaborative tool, with people of the same team sharing
lists together. Nobody on this team has more power than any
other people. Besides, one list can be "moved" between
people of the team : it is possible that the person who
created the list leaves the project.

So it is perfectly possible that somebody with whom you
shared a list does bad things with your list. Of course this
person could erase your list, etc....

But if you share a list with someone with bad intention,
you've got a a problem!!! Why on earth did you share a list
with this person in the very first place?

Concerning your broken account, it's just a refresh problem
: just hit the reload button in your browser and everything
should be just fine.
If you wait 2 minutes, the different parts of the page will
be automatically refreshed, so just waiting a bit should
also "heal" your page.

subject: tudu
title: #1 AJAX does not work with Internet Explorer
description: This is probably just the hand-made AJAXian stuff, not DWR.

Logged In: YES
user_id=1125452

I reported the problem to DWR and got answer from Joe
Walker. Maybe it is the solution but I haven't time to test it.

FYI

The problem I was having was that with drupal you only get to
directly edit the content div of a page. So I put the script tags
from the old header and the old content into a drupal page -
IE treats inline script differently from head script tags and if
you try to do any DOM manipulation (i think this is what
kicked it off) before page load had fired, an error resulted. I
suspect head script elements are executed on page load, but
inline ones earlier so they can document.writeln().

The solution was to use onload. Take a look at the examples
on the dwr site, you can see how the init function is called on
the table page for example.

Logged In: YES
user_id=79744

I just released version 1.0-beta-3, where I have removed all
non-DWR AJAXian stuff from the application.
I hope that the problem was coming from my own stuff, and
not DWR (given the fact that DWR is much more tested than my
code).
However, as I don't have Internet Explorer at home, I just
can't test this version. If somebody has tested version
1.0-berta-3, please post a reply here.
• status: open --> closed
